T HE red deer loves the chaparral, The hawk the wind-rocked pine; The ouzel haunts the rills that race The cañon's steep incline; But the wild sheep from the battered rocks, Sure foot and fleet of limb, Gets up to see the stars go by Along the mountain-rim.

For him the sky-built battlements, For him the cliff and scar, For him the deep-walled chasms Where the roaring rivers are; The gentian-flowered meadow-lands, The tamarack slope and crest, Above the eagle's screaming brood, Above the wild wolf's quest.

When in the riot of the storms The snow-flowers blossom fair, The cattle get them to the plain, The howlers to the lair. The shepherd tends his foolish flocks Along the mountain's hem; But free and far the wild sheep are, And God doth shepherd them.
